title: Homeric Hymns To the Dioscuri 1
body: identification of the Dioskouroi also as sons of Tyndareus, even though they have different fathers (comparison with the twins in Rig Veda)

title: Homeric Hymns To the Dioscuri 1
body: analysis of the association of sheep and salvation in the myth of the Dioskouroi, and the two distinct episodes of the cattle raid and the battle in it

title: Homeric Hymns To the Dioscuri 3
body: comment on the distinction between Castor and Polydeuces in terms of their fixed epithets, Castor as “horsebreaking” and Polydeuces known for his boxing skill (or amōmētos as here)

title: Homeric Hymns To the Dioscuri 5-17
body: the Dioskouroi as saviors of mortals in distress, especially at sea, and comparison with the Vedic (and other Indo-European) twins

title: Homeric Hymns To the Dioscuri 6
body: sōtēres as both an epithet and a cult title of the Dioskouroi

title: Homeric Hymns To the Dioscuri 8-12
body: analysis of the association of sheep and salvation in the myth of the Dioskouroi, and the two distinct episodes of the cattle raid and the battle in it

title: Homeric Hymns To the Dioscuri 18-19
body: example of allēs … aoidēs as meaning not ‘another song’ but ‘the rest of the song’, in the context of the analysis of hymnic moments of metabasis

title: Homeric Hymns To the Dioscuri 18
body: the Dioskouroi as famous horsemen, and the Indo-European origins of this attribute (the same for the Vedic twins)

title: Homeric Hymns To the Dioscuri 18
body: identification of the Dioskouroi also as sons of Tyndareus, even though they have different fathers (comparison with the twins in Rig Veda)
